text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

IRM 4.4.17 has been extensively revised throughout. Names of functional areas have been changed to reﬂect the current organizational structure and the IRM has been reorganized. A summary of signiﬁcant changes is reﬂected below:

IRMSubsection Content Change IRM4.4.17.2.5 Previous procedures for “Possessor of Certain Cash” can be found in IRM 3.13.5.79, IRM 4.8.8.7.1.3.3, IRM 4.8.8.7.1.3.4, IRM 4.15.1.1.6, IRM 4.15.1.9.3.4, IRM 4.15.1.10.6, IRM 4.15.3.1.6, and IRM 4.15.3.2.2. IRM 4.4.17.3 Retitled “Termination Assessments” to “Termination Assessments - Overview” and renumbered IRM 4.4.17.6. IRM4.4.17.3.1(a) Merged “Types of Termination Assessments” into IRM 4.4.17.6.1. IRM4.4.17.3.1(b) Previous procedures for “Types of Termination Assess- ments” for “Possessor of Cash” can be found in IRM 4.15.1.1.6, IRM 4.15.1.9.3.1, IRM 4.15.1.9.3.2, IRM 4.15.1.9.3.4, IRM 4.15.1.9.4, and IRM 4.15.1.10.6. IRM4.4.17.3.1.1 Renumbered IRM 4.4.17.6.1. IRM4.4.17.3.1.2 Previous procedures for “Possessor of Certain Cash” can be found in IRM 3.13.5.79, IRM 4.8.8.7.1.3.3, IRM 4.15.1.1.6, IRM 4.15.1.9.3.4, IRM 4.15.1.9.4, IRM 4.15.1.10.6, and IRM 4.15.3.2.2. IRM4.4.17.3.2 Merged “General Processing” into IRM 4.4.17.6. IRM4.4.17.3.2.1 Renumbered IRM 4.4.17.6.2. IRM4.4.17.3.2.2 Previous procedures for “Post Termination” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.6.1, IRM 4.8.8.13, IRM 4.15.1.5, IRM 4.15.1.7, IRM 4.15.1.7.1, IRM 4.15.1.7.6, and IRM 4.15.1.9.3.4. IRM 4.4.17.3.3 Previous procedures for “Processing the Full Year” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.7, IRM 4.8.8.7.1, IRM 4.8.7.1.1, IRM 4.8.8.7.1.3.2, IRM 4.8.8.7.13.3, IRM 4.15.1.10.2 IRM 4.15.1.10.2.1, and IRM 4.15.1.10.2.2. IRM4.4.17.3.4 Moved “Final Closure of Full Year” to IRM 4.4.17.6.3. IRM 4.4.17.4 Retitled “Transferor/Transferee Cases” to “Transferor/ Transferee Cases - Overview” and renumbered IRM 4.4.17.7. .IRM 4.4.17.4.1 Renumbered IRM 4.4.17.7.1. IRM4.4.17.4.2 Previous procedures for “General Processing Proce- dures” can be found in IRM 3.17.244.3.8, IRM 4.8.8.13.1, IRM 4.8.9.7, IRM 4.8.9.7.6, IRM 4.8.9.17.3, IRM 4.8.9.17.3.1, and IRM 4.10.13.3.7.

IRMSubsection Content Change IRM4.4.17.4.2.1 Previous procedures for “Closing Instructions” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.5.7.5, IRM 4.8.8.13.4, and IRM 4.10.13.3.4.7. IRM4.4.17.4.2.2 Renumbered IRM 4.4.17.7.2. IRM4.4.17.4.2.3 Previous procedures for “Closing Protested to Appeals or Petitioned to Tax Court” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.5.7.2, IRM 4.8.8.7.1.1, IRM 4.8.8.13.4, IRM 4.8.9.14.4, and IRM 4.8.9.17.3. IRM4.4.17.4.2.4 Renumbered IRM 4.4.17.7.3. IRM4.4.17.4.3 Renumbered IRM 4.4.17.4. IRM4.4.17.4.4 Previous procedures for “Limited Liability Involving Multiple Years” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.13.1.1, IRM 4.10.13.3.5.1, and IRM 4.10.13.3.7. IRM4.4.17.4.5 Previous procedures for “IRC 6901(a)(2)” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.13 and IRM 4.8.8.13.1. IRM4.4.17.4.5.1 Previous procedures for “Processing Instructions for 6901(a)(2)” can be found in IRM 4.8.8.13.5 and IRM Exhibit 4.8.8-1. IRM 4.4.17.5 Previous procedures for “Additional Resources” can be found in IRM 3.17.46.4.2, IRM 3.17.46.5, IRM 3.17.46.5.1, and IRM 3.17.63.7.7. IRM Exhibit 4.4.17-1 Previous procedures for “Form 1296 - Assessment Against Transferee or Fiduciary” can be found in IRM Exhibit 4.8.8-1, IRM 4.8.8.13.2, IRM 4.8.8.13.4, and IRM 4.8.8.13.5.
This revision supersedes the previous IRM 4.4.17, dated 07-15-2011.
Large Business and International (LB&I), Wage and Investment (W&I), and Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE) employees.
Signed by Lori L. Roberts Director, Technology Solutions Small Business/Self
Employed Division
Jeopardy Assessments/Termination Assessments/Transferor-Transferee Assessments
Table of Contents

) Purpose: The procedures, which were in this IRM, pertained to the Examina- tion Audit Process. New IRM references for the procedures previously located in this IRM are listed in the material changes. This section provides general instructions for Jeopardy , Termination , and Transferor-Transferee Assess- ments. The Centralized Case Processing (CCP) procedures remaining in this IRM will be included in the new IRM
, Examining Processing, CCP, Or- ganization and Responsibilities. (
) Audience: The audience for this Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section will Examination CCP. (
) Policy Owner: The Director: SB/SE Technology Solutions who is under the Director, Operations Support. (
) Program Owner: Examination Systems and Projects, Customer Service. (

) Program Goals: The goal of this section is to provide an overview of jeopardy and termination provisions of the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). Jeopardy as- sessments give the Commissioner speciﬁc authority to take immediate assessment and collection action in situations where it is determined that col- lection of tax will be endangered if regular assessment and collection procedures are followed. (
) IRM deviations must be submitted in writing to the Director Small Business/ Self-Employed (SB/SE) Division following instructions from IRM
, When Procedures Deviate from the IRM. (

) The procedures, which were in this IRM, pertained to the Examination Audit Process. The procedures do not pertain to the AIMS Information Technologies (IT) System, which is the subject of this IRM. New IRM references for the pro- cedures previously located in this IRM are listed in the material changes. This IRM section provides examiners with information and guidance on the prepara- tion, assessment process and conﬁrmation of the Jeopardy Assessments, Termination Assessments, and Transferor-Transferee Assessments. CCP pro- cedures remaining in this IRM will be included in the new IRM
, Examining Processing, CCP, Organization and Responsibilities. (
) Headquarter Examination is responsible for all policy and procedures related CCP. (
) This chapter covers special types of assessments that require special handling and processing: a. Jeopardy Assessment instructions - See IRM
b. Termination Assessment instructions - See IRM
c. Transferor/Transferee Assessment instructions - See IRM

Purpose: The procedures, which were in this IRM, pertained to the Examina- tion Audit Process. New IRM references for the procedures previously located in this IRM are listed in the material changes. This section provides general instructions for Jeopardy , Termination , and Transferor-Transferee Assess- ments. The Centralized Case Processing (CCP) procedures remaining in this IRM will be included in the new IRM 4.38.1, Examining Processing, CCP, Or- ganization and Responsibilities.
4.4 Audit Information Management System (AIMS) – Validity and Consistency
) Jeopardy Assessment - Overview (

) Jeopardy assessments allow for the collection of taxes in circumstance in which it is determined that collection of tax would be endangered if normal cedures were followed. Jeopardy assessments protects the government’s interest under IRC
(a), Jeopardy Assessment of Income, Estate, Gift Certain Excise Taxes. Jeopardy assessments are immediate assessments made with delay. (
) A jeopardy assessment must be approved by the Area Director and Area Counsel and be made within
hours of the Area Director’s approval - See IRM
, Secure Approval of the Report. Reminder: Written Approval by Area Counsel is required under the provisions of the IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of
Failure to do so will result in the abatement of any assessment made under IRC
) Jeopardy assessments are made on Master File.
) Area Office Procedures - Against the Taxpayer’s Correct TIN (
) A Jeopardy Assessment is an assessment against the Taxpayer’s Correct Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN). (

) The Area Office must provide notice by E-mail or telephone to the CCP Field Office Resource Team (FORT) manager or the Field Liaison as soon as it is known that a jeopardy assessment is being made (preferably within
hours before assessment) .
Assessment - (

) Jeopardy assessments allow for the collection of taxes in circumstance in which it is determined that collection of tax would be endangered if normal pro- cedures were followed. Jeopardy assessments protects the government’s interest under IRC
(a), Jeopardy Assessment of Income, Estate, Gift and Certain Excise Taxes. Jeopardy assessments are immediate assessments made with delay. (
) A jeopardy assessment must be approved by the Area Director and Area Counsel and be made within
hours of the Area Director’s approval - See IRM
, Secure Approval of the Report.

Reminder: Written Approval by Area Counsel is required under the provisions of the IRS Restructuring and Reform Act of 1998. Failure to do so will result in the abatement of any assessment made under IRC 6201..

A Jeopardy Assessment is an assessment against the Taxpayer’s Correct Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN). The Area Office must provide notice by E-mail or telephone to the CCP Field Office Resource Team (FORT) manager or the Field Liaison as soon as it is known that a jeopardy assessment is being made (preferably within
hours before assessment) .
Reminder: A Jeopardy Assessment requires approval from the Area Director and Area Counsel and the assessment made within

hours of the approval. Therefore, the Area Office should notify CCP the same day the approval is sought so that by the time it is approved by the Area Director and Area Counsel, the Area Office is ready to EFax the prelimi- nary paper work to the FORT manager or Field Liaison (with
hours).
Reminder: A Jeopardy Assessment requires approval from the Area Director and
a. Form
, Recommendation for Jeopardy/Termination Assessment (Prepare in triplicate) with the Area Director’s signature; b. Area Counsel’s Approval Memorandum; c. Completed Form
, Special Handling Notice for Examination Case Processing, for each year; d. Completed Form

, Income Tax Examination Changes, with all schedules for years, and f. Speciﬁc written instructions stating to whom the FORT manager should EFax the completed Form
, Prompt Assessment Billing Assembly, once the assessment is made.
Note: Typically the Technical Services Manager and the Collection Officer are des- ignated to receive the EFaxed Form 3552.
The original Form 2644 will be sent to the FORT manager via express mail.

) A termination assessment is made when it is found that a taxpayer would to prejudice, or to render wholly or partially ineffectual, the collection of taxes for a current or immediately preceding taxable year, unless collection proceedings are brought without delay (
) Each termination assessment must be approved by the Area Director (or delegate) and Area Chief Counsel (or delegate). (
) Termination Assessment: a. Against the Taxpayer’s Correct TIN IRC
and (
) A termination assessment consists of two parts: a. Assessment of the short tax period (the termination period) and b. Assessment of the full tax period (the taxpayer’s normal tax year). (
) A Termination Assessment is one of two types of an assessment. (
) Termination applies if a return is not yet due (including extensions) and can a partial year. (
) Since a return is not yet due, the case is controlled on Non-Master File using Form
, Examination Request Non-Master File. (
) An immediate assessment is made on the termination year. (
) After the assessment is made, the case is held in suspense pending action the taxpayer. (
) A Transaction Code (TC)
, “Active Criminal Investigation” is placed on Master File account and should not be removed until a return is ﬁled or a return is due and not ﬁled and Master File controls are needed.
The assessment officer will telephone the Technical Services Manager and the Collection Officer to acknowledge the assessment has been made. After processing, a conﬁrmation copy of Form
and Form
is EFaxed to both the Technical Services Manager and the Collection Officer (per the original instructions) and must be associated with the control copy (submitted and assessed Form
and Form
) in CCP. Additional resources: IRM

A termination assessment is made when it is found that a taxpayer would act to prejudice, or to render wholly or partially ineffectual, the collection of income taxes for a current or immediately preceding taxable year, unless collection proceedings are brought without delay Each termination assessment must be approved by the Area Director (or delegate) and Area Chief Counsel (or delegate).
The assessment officer will telephone the Technical Services Manager and the Collection Officer to acknowledge the assessment has been made.
Assessment of the short tax period (the termination period) and Assessment of the full tax period (the taxpayer’s normal tax year).
Jeopardy Assessments/Termination Assessments/Transferor-Transferee Assessments 4.4.17
of a Year (
) When the assessment involves the termination of a taxpayer’s year, the for the terminated tax period is handled as a jeopardy assessment at the of termination - See IRM
) The package sent to the FORT by the Area is the same as described for Jeopardy Assessments IRM
except Form
is not prepared. (
) The termination assessment is made as a short period NMF assessment. (

) To prevent possible forfeiture of lien rights, the original short period assess- ment must not at any time (prior to determination of the tax liability for the year) be reduced to an amount less than the current tax liability for the full year. (
) When the case is received by Processing for assessment of the full period, termination NMF assessment will be transferred to Master File. Closure of Full (
) When the case is ready for ﬁnal closure on the full year, process the case follows: a. After ensuring the TC
(Active Criminal Investigation) has been released, input TC
using Form
, Notice of Action for Entity Master File. b. Request the assessment done by Service Center Accounting on the short period (termination assessment) be transferred to Master File using Form
, Adjustment Request. • The transfer will be with a TC
and will maintain the
C date to officially assess tax liabilities). The
C date is the TC

posting date of the original termination assessment. • If the combined termination period and full period credits exceed the combined debts, request that Accounting transfer the credits with a secondary TC
for $
to hold the credits until the TC
posts.
The package sent to the FORT by the Area is the same as described for Jeopardy Assessments IRM 4.4.17.5.1 except Form 5344 is not prepared.
When the case is received by Processing for assessment of the full period, the termination NMF assessment will be transferred to Master File.
When the case is ready for ﬁnal closure on the full year, process the case as
a. After ensuring the TC
(Active Criminal Investigation) has been released, input TC
using Form
, Notice of Action for Entity on Master File. b. Request the assessment done by Service Center Accounting on the NMF short period (termination assessment) be transferred to Master File using Form
, Adjustment Request.

) A transferor is one who created the tax liability and transferred assets that could potentially satisfy the tax liability to another party or multiple parties. transferor may be a corporation, an individual or an estate. (

) A transferee is the person(s) or entity/entities that received the assets for than full, fair and adequate consideration and who is additionally liable for tax due to this transfer. A transferee may be a corporation, an individual, an estate or an executor or administrator of an estate or a ﬁduciary or a combina- tion of these entities. (
) A transferee is the person(s) or entity(ies) who received the assets for less than full, fair and adequate consideration and who is additionally liable for tax due to this transfer. (
) A transferee may be a corporation, an individual, an estate or an executor administrator of an estate or a ﬁduciary or a combination of these entities. (
) If multiple transferees exist, each transferee is controlled separately.
4.4.17.7 (03-24-2023) Transferor/TransfereeCases-Overview
A transferee may be a corporation, an individual, an estate or an executor or administrator of an estate or a ﬁduciary or a combination of these entities.
If multiple transferees exist, each transferee is controlled separately.
) The transferee individual/entity will have the title ″ Transferee ″ after the trans- feree’s name. Instructions (
) IRM

),Examining Officers Guide (EOG) - Transferee Liability Cases, instructs the ﬁeld group employees (LB&I, W&I and SB/SE) to establish a transferee case as a “DUMMY” record. a. ERCS will not allow both a Master File and a Non-Master File (NMF) control for the same person/entity. b. AIMS will not allow a Social Security Number (SSN) with a Business Master File (BMF) Master File Transaction (MFT) code. c. A “DUMMY” ﬁle must be established for the transferee case using the transferee’s TIN with “-D” (“DUMMY”) and the title “Transferee” after name to indicate transferee status. d. Using the “ -D ” eliminates the other dashes in the TINS so both ERCS and AIMS will accept the number with the NMF MFT of the transferor. Example: Smith, John, Transferee,
-D, MFT
, or Big Trucks, Transferee,
-D, MFT

Audit Information Management System (AIMS) – Validity and Consistency
4.4 Audit Information Management System (AIMS) – Validity and Consistency

Prepare a copy of the transferee administrative ﬁle to be associated with the transferor ﬁle under the TC 421 DLN of the transferor TIN. Close the transferee NMF “N” record(s) on ERCS to CCP Status Code 51 with Disposal Code 10 or 13, as appropriate.
Note: ERCS will update the AIMS record with the new status. Prepare the Form
for the “-D” record to be deleted from AIMS. Forward the Form
to the local AIMS/ERCS staff for processing using Disposal Code
or AMNON “D” . Include the copy of the trans- feree administrative ﬁle to be associated with the transferor ﬁle. The AIMS/ERCS unit will process the Form
and will forward the transferee administrative ﬁle to the campus to be associated with the transferor ﬁle using the TC
DLN found on Master File.
